Fields.DialogueText: *KABOOM*
Morganas!
Stand back, Capitano. Leave everything to me.
@BATTLE
Fine work out there as usual, Cara.
Grazie, Capitano. Now, if you'll excuse me...
Why are you in such a hurry?
I… uh… No reason in particular.

Fields.MenuText: That bulge in your pocket looks awfully like a lighter.

Fields.DialogueText: You must be seeing things. This is my… spare pair of handcuffs! You can never be too-- Who am I kidding?

Fields.MenuText: I know when you're lying.

Fields.DialogueText: I should have known better than to try and pull the wool over your eyes.
I knew I could rely on that honesty of yours.
Apologies, Capitano. I was planning on going for a smoke break.
I really don't mean to pressure you, but literally just yesterday you were saying-

Fields.MenuText: Very well.

Fields.DialogueText: … Fine! I'm lying, is that what you wanted to hear?
Lo so, lo so! I said I didn't want to go back to smoking. I say that a lot! And I mean it!
And then it happens anyway.
... Would it help if I took custody of that lighter?
Probabilmente... starting tomorrow.
Really?
Bene! Here! Thank you!
... Dismissed.
There you are, Cara.
Is everything all right, Capitano?
I had a thought. Perhaps we could try some incentives to help you quit smoking.
I assure you, I've tried it all before.
My idea was, whenever you get a craving, you'll do ten pushups or something similar.
That's a rather basic idea, don't you think?
Ah, but here's the rub. If you ever give into temptation, we throw out one random item of clothing from your wardrobe.
... You are a dangerous one, aren't you, Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: Well, if you think you don't have the willpower…

Fields.DialogueText: Reverse psychology won't work on me, Capitano. But I will agree to your terms to prove to myself that I can do this.

Fields.MenuText: What do you say?

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate you racking your brain so much. It would be rude not to give it at least a try.
*ALARM*
Morganas!
I suppose if I can't smoke tobacco, I'll have to smoke something else!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I just want to help however I can.

Fields.DialogueText: I can see that, don't worry. Very well, let's try out your plan.
You wanted to see me, Capitano?
Yes, please come in and take a seat.
Si.
We have a new assignment, Cara. An INPF carrier has sustained heavy damage and is currently on the run from a fleet of Morganas.
We should lend whatever aid we can at once!
That's exactly what we will do. We're to take the shortest route from here to a stretch of coast near Punta Stilo and lend our support.
Punta Stilo in Calabria…
You know the area?
Somewhat. Not particularly. I doubt any general knowledge I possess would be of much use.
Regardless, we'll have to do the best we can to fend off the Morganas and ensure the carrier ship makes port safely.
Understood.

Fields.MenuText: Any questions?

Fields.DialogueText: None whatsoever. You've made yourself perfectly clear, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: What do you think of our chances?

Fields.DialogueText: Considering this is a rescue mission, I won't allow us to fail. I'll lose my life before I allow anyone else to come to harm.
*ALARM*
That should do it for this debriefing. After we take care of the Morganas, you're free to go on break.
Si, Capitano!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: It's been a while since our last mission.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm ready to go whenever!
We're making good time.
Si, Capitano. We should be caught up with the carrier sooner than we thought.
Is that the reason you're shooting cans on the deck? Something to quell the excitement of another rescue mission?
Maybe somewhat. It's always good to keep up with things like this or my skill could turn stale.
Do I sense a strange undercurrent to those words?
I may be trying anything I can to keep my mind off smoking as well. Training makes for a good distraction.

Fields.MenuText: You're looking finer by the day.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you still talking about my shooting skill?

Fields.MenuText: Not going well then, I presume.

Fields.DialogueText: I've had better days…
The way you're going, we'll run out of cans before the war ends. You're a real crack shot.
Grazie, Capitano.
*ALARM*
How about we put that rifle to better use!
Si, Capitano!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Is there anything I can do to help?

Fields.DialogueText: No, your company is more than enough.
How's it going, Cara? This is the three-day hump now.
I'm feeling much better, Capitano!
Your face looks a lot brighter now as well.
Perhaps as a reward for my good efforts, we could take in a spot of horseback riding during our next docking.
I don't see why not.
Grazie, Capitano. Of course, I'd much prefer to have my own stallion aboard the ship, but…

Fields.MenuText: There's precedent with other Belles.

Fields.DialogueText: Though, compared to some of the crew, a horse might be a nice change of pace.

Fields.MenuText: First chance we get, we'll spend the entire day riding in circles around the dock.

Fields.DialogueText: With passionate words like that, how can I resist?
... There is the example of Texas, of course.
If you can create your own robotic horse too, I'm all for it.
*ALARM*
Table the discussion until after the Morganas are sunk?
Agreed.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I don't think that's the best idea…

Fields.DialogueText: I don't see why not.
Si - but not Belles I consider to be valuable role models.
Go on. Rub it in.
Hey, I'm not-
Capitano, care to join me?
I very much would. I see you got the last slice of chocolate cake.
Guilty as charged. I guess I'm pretty lucky.
As am I, if you plan to share at least half of it.
Unfortunately, if I were to hand off some of this dessert to you, it would inadvertently make me unlucky, don't you think?
How do you figure?
Well, I would have been lucky to have grabbed the cake, but unlucky to have run into you here and now.
I'm not following.
Trust me, the forces that be almost forbid me from sharing this with you.

Fields.MenuText: Are you pretty lucky in all walks of life?

Fields.DialogueText: I would like to think so. My good fortune brought me into your care, after all.

Fields.MenuText: How about we make a trade for a bite of that cake?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, now. What do you have that I want?
*ALARM*
Dammit!
Let's go, Capitano. Don't try and sneak a bite before I get back!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Is there a secret to this luck?

Fields.DialogueText: Hard work and dedication, of course. That and striking an accord with the mess workers.
Capitano, look! That appears to be the carrier on the horizon!
And that looks like quite a few Morganas on its tail. Let's lend our aid!
@BATTLE
It was lucky we arrived when we did.
Right you are. It looks as though all cargo and crew are present and accounted for, however.
Our mission isn't over yet.
Certo. The drop-off location is still quite a ways away, but as long as we steer clear of any potential danger zones, we should be able to pass by undetected.

Fields.MenuText: It will be difficult to take on the Morganas while also trying to defend the carrier.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not so sure about that, Capitano. I have confidence in my own abilities. My only worry is wasting our scarce resources.

Fields.MenuText: How are the crew? Did you speak with them?

Fields.DialogueText: The captain seemed at his wit's end, but who can blame him after all they've been through? I can tell he was glad to see us.

Fields.MenuText: Do we need to be so stealthy?

Fields.DialogueText: It's always better to avoid conflict whenever possible, don't you think? We can save our ammunition that way. Who knows when we'll be blindsided and need to fire our way out of a sticky situation?
The carrier looks ready to move out.
Let's make a move before any more Morganas show up.
Target practice again, Cara?
Rescue missions always light a fire inside me, Capitano.
I can see that.
This is the only way I can release that pent-up energy.
*Chuckle*
Something funny, Capitano?
You never met a Morgana you couldn't handle. Cigarettes... now, those are the real challenge.
Didn't your mother ever tell you to do as she says and not as she does?

Fields.MenuText: So you're my mother now?

Fields.DialogueText: You can think of me that way if you like. You and the rest of the crew are in my care, after all.

Fields.MenuText: And what do YOU say?

Fields.DialogueText: I say, allow me to do my job and turn a blind eye to anything suspicious you see me doing!

Fields.MenuText: Forgive me. I'll keep my thoughts to myself next time.

Fields.DialogueText: Apologies, Capitano. As you can tell, I'm a little on edge.
Shall I fetch you some more cans?
Actually, there's a picture frame in my room. Perhaps you could bring me that instead?
Wait, if I remember correctly, the only portrait in your room is of Texas.
Yes, that's the one.
But--
*ALARM*
We'll have to finish this later, Capitano! We have company!
@BATTLE
Capitano, look!
What, what is it?!
In the water! I could swear I saw…
Not this again…
It was! It had to have been! There's no other explanation for a tail that large!
How many times do I have to tell you. Mermaids don't exist!
Perhaps we could send someone down there to have a look.

Fields.MenuText: And maybe I should send someone to Transylvania to check if Dracula is okay.

Fields.DialogueText: Demon ships arrive from another plane and sentient ships arrive to stop them, but yes, I'm the crazy one for thinking a half-man half-fish MIGHT exist…

Fields.MenuText: I'll send someone down there to have a look if it'll satisfy you.

Fields.DialogueText: That's not a bad idea anyway, Capitano. We may manage to salvage something worthwhile.
*ALARM*
Capitano, let's drive them out!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: What fairy tale inspired you this time?

Fields.DialogueText: "Fairy tale" connotes untruth. Myths and fables, now - there are lessons in those, even if they aren't real.
Hello there, Cara.
Capitano, would you care to join me?
Don't mind if I do. What are you reading?
Just another of my favorite mystery novels.
Agatha Christie?
The very same.

Fields.MenuText: You prefer foreign mysteries over Italian ones?

Fields.DialogueText: Between you and I, Italian mysteries feel a little...
Politiical?
Your words, not mine.
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: Do you have a penchant for any other genre?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not opposed to the occasional romance novel now and again.

Fields.MenuText: How is it so far?

Fields.DialogueText: The case has only just begun, but I feel as though I have a strong inclination as to who the culprit may be.
I'm sure there's no mystery as to who's behind this sudden attack.
I'm right behind you, Capitano!
@BATTLE
Morganas!
Quickly, everyone! To your positions!
@BATTLE
They're pressing us hard!
Capitano, I have a plan!
Quickly now!
If we can make it behind that island, we should be able to lose them!

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure?

Fields.DialogueText: It's worth a shot!

Fields.MenuText: Let's give it a try!

Fields.DialogueText: Making evasive maneuvers!

Fields.MenuText: We can't fight back?

Fields.DialogueText: There's no need! Trust me, I'll make sure the carrier doesn't sustain any damage!
You heard the Belle! Get us out of here!
The Morganas are out of sight, Capitano.
Thank goodness. That was a fine idea you had back there.
Perhaps all the mystery novels I've read have finally started to make themselves worthwhile.
How so?
Something clicked inside me back there. I could just see a way out.

Fields.MenuText: I don't suppose you have a way out of the war.

Fields.DialogueText: Let's not get ahead of ourselves.

Fields.MenuText: You'd make a mighty fine detective.

Fields.DialogueText: At least I know there will be work for me once the war ends.

Fields.MenuText: Good job.

Fields.DialogueText: Grazie, Capitano. I'm just glad we all made it out safely.
*ALARM*
Maybe we spoke too soon.
There are only a few stragglers, Capitano. It looks as though they've been separated from a larger fleet.
Let's dispatch them quickly. Be mindful of our charge.
@BATTLE
I see the mess is pretty empty right now.
A few of the crewmen went up to the deck for a smoke break.
Are you okay?
I'll be fine.
Cara...
Honestly, Capitano... sometimes I think you were right about this thing. Being tougher than the Morganas, I mean.
How do you figure?
The need to smoke just won't leave my mind. Even for a day or two it will pop up now and again. I suppose I'll never be able to completely stop thinking about it until the day I die.

Fields.MenuText: That is a scary thought.

Fields.DialogueText: At least I can act as a warning to others who are thinking of dipping their toes in.

Fields.MenuText: It's that strong?

Fields.DialogueText: It comes and goes, but there will always be that hint of desire lurking beneath the surface.

Fields.MenuText: I'm proud of you.

Fields.DialogueText: Grazie...
*ALARM*
The Morganas should make for a nice distraction.
Allow me to assist you.
@BATTLE
You're up early, Cara.
Am I not allowed to do target practice in the morning?
Not at all, I just thought--
Then there's no problem, is there?
I didn't mean to offend you.
*Sigh* Scusa, Capitano. I'm a little on edge this morning. This smoking ban is really starting to get to me.
Shall I leave you to your own devices?
No, no. Why are you up so early?
I'm always up at the crack of dawn. I need to keep my eyes peeled, you know.
This war continues to drag on, doesn't it? I'll be glad when it's all over.

Fields.MenuText: What will you do when that day comes?

Fields.DialogueText: Relax in a nice warm bath and a good read. I can't think of a better way to spend my time.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure it'll be over soon.

Fields.DialogueText: As do I. If I have anything to say about it, at least.

Fields.MenuText: We're doing everything we can.

Fields.DialogueText: I wonder how things will pan out after the global threat has disappeared. It would be nice to share what comes after.
*ALARM*
It's a good thing we were up so early.
Rise and shine, you lot! We have business to attend to!
@BATTLE
Capitano, do you have a spare pen and something to write on?
Um... Sure, here.
Grazie.
Can I ask why?
We'll be docked for some time, correct? I thought I'd send someone on a little shopping trip in my stead.

Fields.MenuText: Do you need new clothes?

Fields.DialogueText: My wardrobe has been looking a little thin recently.

Fields.MenuText: I thought your wardrobe was packed!

Fields.DialogueText: That was quite a while ago, Capitano. Besides, I have to make sure I'm sporting the latest fashion at all times.

Fields.MenuText: Why don't you go yourself?

Fields.DialogueText: And who will defend the ship if we come under fire?
Very well, but tell whoever you send to be quick about it.
Once we're packed and ready to go, we'll head back out to sea. We'll likely have to defend the carrier from any Morganas blocking our exit.
Si!
@BATTLE
I see all your clothes have arrived. This is quite the haul.
Fire sale from a damaged shop. I had the crewmate snap up everything she could find.
So, what now? Will you model all of these individually?
Oh, no, Capitano. That pen wasn't for a list, it was for me to copy the designs.
Ah, I see.
This way, I can create my own unique clothes tailor-made for my body type.

Fields.MenuText: What will you do with the leftovers?

Fields.DialogueText: Charity. The least I can do is get these clothes onto needy backs.

Fields.MenuText: That's a good way to make some extra money.

Fields.DialogueText: You misunderstand, Capitano. I won't sell the clothes I bought. These will be charitable donations.

Fields.MenuText: What's wrong with wearing these off-the-rack clothes?

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing, per se. But my wardrobe should have my flair - until I donate it to charity, that is.
*ALARM*
Something tells me these Morganas aren't here for clothes.
I'll have to finish up here later!
@BATTLE
Target practice again, Cara?
Care to join me this time, Capitano?
Do you mind?
Of course not. Come here.
Here, let me take this.
Now take aim at the can…
Like this.
Perfect. Now, relax your shoulders. And release!
I did it!
Excellent, Capitano!

Fields.MenuText: You're a pretty good teacher.

Fields.DialogueText: You're a pretty good student.

Fields.MenuText: How did you get so good at this?

Fields.DialogueText: Practice makes perfect!
*ALARM*
Let's put your practice to the test, Capitano!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we could do this again sometime?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course. Whenever you want to try again, just let me know.
You've really been improving ever since we started meeting to practice your aim, Capitano.
It's all thanks to you.
I can't possibly take all the credit. It takes a lot of motivation to meet at such early hours.
I wake up early anyway.
Then I'll say no more.

Fields.MenuText: Is there any reason you want to train with a rifle so much?

Fields.DialogueText: I know it won't do much good against a Morganas hull, but it keeps my senses sharp and my reflexes in check.

Fields.MenuText: I'm feeling pretty confident. How about if I miss this next can, I cook you dinner? And if I hit it-

Fields.DialogueText: Don't write checks you're not prepared to cash, Capitano.
*ALARM*
Let's cut this training short, Capitano. I hope you've been paying attention.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Are you partial to any other kinds of weapons? Or martial arts, perhaps?

Fields.DialogueText: One hopes never to have to close to melee range, but versatility pays.
What are you doing out here, Cara?
Something along the winds... I feel like something bad is about to happen.

Fields.MenuText: To us?
Morganas?
Are you okay?

Fields.DialogueText: Things have been too... easy. I didn't expect the Morganas to just let us have the carrier.
I believe so.
At the moment. Almost too fine.
*ALARM*
It's just a few Morganas, right? Nothing we haven't handled before.
Right. Allow me to deal with them. Let's make sure the cargo arrives safely.
@BATTLE
There's too many of them, Capitano!
We'll have to fight back!
Not yet, Capitano! Allow me to try some evasive maneuvers first!

Fields.MenuText: I think we can take them!

Fields.DialogueText: There's no need! Please, I can handle this!

Fields.MenuText: Why don't we face them?

Fields.DialogueText: We need to maintain our ammo! Besides, we should prioritize protecting the carrier at all costs!

Fields.MenuText: This is no time to be passive!

Fields.DialogueText: You don't need to shed blood to win a battle! I'll prove it to you!
Fine! I'm putting a lot of trust in you!
I won't let you down!
@BATTLE
They're still on us!
I don't understand... Usually everything works out when I hatch a plan.
Cara...
Why is this not working?!
Cara! Snap out of it!
Capitano... I don't know what we should do!
We'll turn and fight!
Isn't it too late for that now?
Yes. The carrier is in the line of fire since its lagging behind our evasive maneuvers.
What should we do?
We'll tell them to dump their cargo and speed ahead of us.
But then the mission will be considered a failure!

Fields.MenuText: The crew's lives take precedence over everything right now.
We have no other choice.
That's an order.

Fields.DialogueText: Si, Capitano...
This is all my fault...
Right. Of course.
I'll radio them You lay down as much suppressing fire as you can.
Understood!
@BATTLE
We made it out safely...
Along with the carrier.
And the cargo?
Lost to the depths.
*Sigh*

Fields.MenuText: It's not your fault.
Are you okay?
I'll take responsibility.

Fields.DialogueText: Grazie, but I don't see anyone else whose fault it could be.
Capitano... I'm so sorry.
There's the dock up ahead. Let's get the crew to safety.
Leave the Morganas to me. I won't make the same mistake twice.
@BATTLE
I've just finished speaking with the carrier's captain.
How did it go?
I explained the situation and he was perfectly understanding.
Really?
Apparently, he had long been convinced that the mission would be a failure. He was only trying to save his and his crew's lives.
I see.
Yes, he was happy to have just made it back safely.
Well, that is a relief.

Fields.MenuText: You still look down.
That's the right way to think about it.

Fields.DialogueText: Even if one has to work to feel that way?
It still stings whenever I think about it.

Fields.MenuText: I told him it was my fault.

Fields.DialogueText: You didn't have to do that.
Any and all actions that happen aboard my vessel are my responsibility.
Now, let's get back out to sea and await our next assignment.
Si, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Well... we'll be distracted soon enough.
You wanted to see me, Capitano?
Yes, come in. I just wanted to see how you're holding up.
To be met face to face with my own naiveté... It's going to take some time for me to get back to my old self, I think.
I just wanted to say that I'm proud of you for not smoking in this stressful time.
Cara?
*ALARM*
I need to show you something, Capitano. Let's deal with these Morganas first.
@BATTLE
My god, how many empty packs is that?
I'd rather not count.

Fields.MenuText: The whole time?

Fields.DialogueText: Unfortunately, yes.

Fields.MenuText: But you seemed agitated.

Fields.DialogueText: I remember I snapped at you once. That was 24 hours where I tried to take this challenge seriously again. It was short-lived.

Fields.MenuText: Where have you been going?

Fields.DialogueText: In the engine room...
I see my punishment has gone unnoticed as well.
Cara?
Come with me, Capitano...
Your wardrobe was completely empty...
I kept my word every step of the way. Every time I smoked, I threw out an item of clothing.

Fields.MenuText: Is that why you sent someone to pick up new clothes for you?

Fields.DialogueText: It is.

Fields.MenuText: You must have thrown out hundreds of clothes!

Fields.DialogueText: I donated them to charity. Still, a punishment I adapt to is no punishment at all.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose that is something at least.

Fields.DialogueText: Quite the opposite. I love clothes, but to let an addiction get to the point where it controls my life is too much...
Cara...
I suppose both the war effort and this will both take a lot more work than I thought.
*ALARM*
Join me on the deck, Cara. After we handle these Morganas, let us recomvene. I have something I want to say to you.
@BATTLE
I'm proud of you.
Capitano?
It takes guts to admit you have a problem. Just as it does to admit fault. Willingness to change is where true courage is born.
You think so?
Don't worry, Cara. Everyone has setbacks. You worry so much about protecting humans from themselves that there's no one left to protect you.
What are you saying?
It's okay to let other people help you sometimes. I'll always be there to lend a hand.
Grazie, Capitano. I hope we can continue our partnership until the war draws to a close.
